snippet: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.
abstract: Stockton, Calif, sold $125 million of bonds to try to close a shortfall in its pension plans for current and retired city workers, but the strategy backfired, leading to the city's bankruptcy; underwriter Lehman Brothers understated the risks of the bonds; analysts say the same pitch that swayed Stockton has been made to thousands of local governments nationwide, and many of them were drawn into deals that have cost them dearly.
lead_paragraph: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.
